title: PCT 24: A Blackfoot adulteress and her Salteau husband
author: Mrs. Maggie Achenam

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êsah iskwêw mistahi kiyiskwêw, êkwah êh-onâpêmit pikw âwiyah nâpêwah oskinîkiwah, êkwah êh-âyimisit.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê êsa iskwêw mistahi kiyiskwêw êkwa ê-onâpêmit piko awiya nâpêwa oskinîkiwa êkwa ê-âyimisit
sentences.english: Once upon a time, the story goes, a certain woman was very silly; she would consort with any man or youth, and she was very troublesome.
Once her husband caught her with another man and gave her a sound beating.
She went away.
She had a small child, which she carried on her back.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê kâwi kîwêw; kotakah wîwiyiwa onâpêmah; kisiwâsiw.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê kâwi kîwêw kotaka wîwiyiwa onâpêma kisiwâsiw
sentences.english: After a while she went back home; her husband had taken another wife; she was angry.

sentences.original: sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw; kotakah iskwêwah sipwêhtahêw.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw kotaka iskwêwa sipwêhtahêw
sentences.english: The man went away; he took the other woman along with him.
Then that woman ran after them.
She kept calling to him, “I'll throw away your child!”
The man went away just the same.

sentences.original: wâhya mtonih êy-ispatinâk, wêpinêw êkotê ocawâsimisah iskwêw awa.
sentences.text: wâhyaw mitoni ê-ispatinâk wêpinêw êkotê ocawâsimisa iskwêw awa
sentences.english: Far away on a hill that woman abandoned her child.
Then she came back home.

sentences.original: êkwah ocawâsimisah nakatêw, ispatinâhk êh-wêpinât, êh-apisîsisiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa ocawâsimisa nakatêw ispatinâhk ê-wêpinât ê-apisîsisiyit
sentences.english: She left her child, abandoning it on a hill, a baby.
“To the wolves I feed this little girl.”
Then she ran back yonder.
As she stayed there in their house, her husband arrived.
“Where is my daughter?” he asked her.
“I have abandoned her.”
“Go fetch her!” he ordered her.
He gave her a terrible beating.
She went off; she went to fetch her daughter.
She could not find her.
Other people had found her.
She came back.
“Where is she?” her husband asked her.
“I have lost her.”
Again he gave her a terrible beating.
He went away again.
The woman pursued her husband.
“Go home!” he bade her.
“No! Please come home!” she said to her husband.
Then another man came to where that woman was.
She told him all kinds of things, “I am not sorry about him.
I am glad he is gone.
I love you much more,” she told him;
“This  is the kind of thing I like.
Now let us go off to my house.
We shall sleep there.”
They came to the woman's house.
Then, after dark, the man went away.
The woman slept alone.
During the night her husband came home.
He lay outside the tent; he conversed with her.
“Come inside,” she told him;
“My husband went away long ago.”
But it was her husband who had arrived.
So now, “No,” said he;
“Your husband may come, for all I know,” he told her.

sentences.original: namoya, itwêw iskwêw, aspin wâhyaw êh-atimohtêt.
sentences.english: “No,” said the woman; “He has gone far away.”
“Oh, no! I am afraid of your husband.”
“Do come in!” said the woman.
“Well,” said the man, “I shall go in.”
Then the woman lay with him.
sentences.footnote: LB on {mâh-mâsihêw}:  Literally, “wrestle”; in the present sense a common and, strangely enough, euphemistic expression.

sentences.english: “Your husband may come any minute.

sentences.original: êkâya sôhki pâhpi; ta-takosin kinâpêm; ka-pakamahokonaw.
sentences.english: Do not laugh aloud;  your husband will be coming; he will beat us.”
“No,” said the woman; “No.
He is far away; he will not be coming.”
Still she lay with that man.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êkwah ocihciyiw otinam; ocahcanisiyiwa otinimêw.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê êkwa ocihcîyiw otinam ocâhcanisiyiwa otinimêw
sentences.english: Presently she took his hand;  she took a ring from his finger.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Our narratress forgets to develop this motif.

sentences.original: êkwah nâpêw, kâ wiyah! kiwîkimâkan kika-pakamahok, takohtêci.
sentences.english: Then the man, “Don't! Your husband will beat you when  he comes.”
“He cannot possibly be coming,” she answered him.
“Do you love your husband very much?”
“No,” answered the woman,
“I hate him.
I am glad he is gone.”
“But you lamented at his going.”
“No.
I only pretended to weep, but I was really glad when he went,” she told him.
sentences.footnote: LB on {êh-kotêsi-miywêyihtamân}:  The particle {kotêsi} here compounded with the verb is otherwise unknown to me and may be wrongly recorded.

sentences.english: “So there we have it! So you really are as crazy as all that, Red-Glow!
This is the end of you.
Without delay now I shall kill you.”
And really he seized her; he began to choke her.
“It was because I recognized you, and on purpose, that I spoke to you that way!”
“No! I shall beat you within an inch of your life.”
He beat her as if to knock the insides out of her.
Then at last he left her alone.
Then she slept.
When morning came, you would have wondered what she ever had looked like.
Her face  was like a kettle.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êh-miyw-ayât êkwah, kâ-takosiniyit ayîsiyiniwah, ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê ê-miyo-ayât êkwa kâ-takosiniyit ayîsiyiniwa ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Presently, after she had recovered, some people arrived, some Blackfoot.
They held ceremonial dances.
“Go join in the singing, Red-Glow.”
“Yes,” she said.
“But come home early,” he told her.
“Yes,” she said.
So off she went.
She danced and sang.
She celebrated with zeal.
But in their tent her child cried and cried.
At last the man got angry.
He took a forked stick.
Then he went there;
there was his wife still a-dancing.
He did not speak;
he caught her neck in the stick and shoved her that way out into the open.

sentences.original: hê, awênah môhcôhkâsôwak ? itwêw aw îskwêw;
sentences.english: “Hey, for whom am I pretending to be crazy?” cried the woman;
“Don't!”
She did not know what to do.
Her husband shoved her along all the way home.
When they were near their tent, she recognized her husband.
Then she went in.
She was afraid of him, and went and nursed her infant.
Her husband, “How now, Red-Glow?”
She was at a loss; she did not know what to do, this woman.
Presently they had games again, in their tent.
One of her lovers was there.
“Now heat some water.”
“There isn't any water,” she said.
“Fetch snow.”
“Very well.”

sentences.original: êkwah askihkwah otinêw; nâtêw êkwah kônah.
sentences.text: êkwa askihkwa otinêw nâtêw êkwa kôna
sentences.english: So she took her kettle; she went to fetch snow.
Then, when she came back, she peeped into the tent.
She saw her lover there.
Then suddenly she stumbled into the opening; she fell into the tent.
“What's this again, Red-Glow?”
“I fell.”
“No! It was because you were peeping in at your lover!”
Now she feared her husband; she sat with her head wrapped up.
“How comes it you are ashamed now, you lewd dog, Red-Glow?”
Then in the morning she went away; she fled.
She hid herself.
She walked every day and slept out of doors.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê sâkêwêw, spatinâhk kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa êh-pâpayiyit.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê sâkêwêw ispatinâhk kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa ê-pâpayiyit
sentences.english: Presently she came out upon a place where she saw a man riding that way over a hill.
She hid.
When she saw him no longer, she went on.
sentences.footnote: Book has no space between {êk} and {êh-wâpamât}.

sentences.original: âsay mînah ê-sâkêwêt, kâ-wâpamât âsay mna êh-pâpayiyit; kâsôhtawêw.
sentences.text: âsay mîna ê-sâkêwêt kâ-wâpamât âsay mîna ê-pâpayiyit kâsôhtawêw
sentences.english: When she came out over the next hill, she saw him again riding toward her; she hid from him.
She set out when she saw him no longer.
She reached a place where there were many tipis.
This time too she came to where her lover was.
He hid her in different places.
Her husband came there, looking for her;
but the other man kept her away from her husband.
“Now he will kill me without delay,” she thought, “if he finds me.”
She fled.
As she was walking along, presently she saw a man.
When she made to run away, he called to her.
“Don't!” he called to her;
“Don't run away!
You can't get away from me.”
So she stopped; she waited for him.
He rode up to where she was.
“Get ready; make your dress as light as you can.”

sentences.original: êkwah omaskisinah otinam, otâsah mînah, oskocâkâs.
sentences.text: êkwa omaskisina otinam otâsa mîna oskocâkâs
sentences.english: Then she took her moccasins, and her leggings, and her blouse.
She tied them to the saddle.
“Now, be off!” he told her;
“Straight on in this direction,”  he told her, “run!”

sentences.original: êkwah aniy ê-sipwêpahtât, itêh kâ-kîh-ôhtôhtêt êkot ê-ispahtât.
sentences.text: êkwa ani ê-sipwêpahtât itê kâ-kî-ohtohtêt êkota ê-ispahtât
sentences.english: So then she set out at a run, and ran in the direction from which she had come.
She kept up with her husband's horse.
He kept prodding her in the back.
When they had run at a slow pace until morning, suddenly he threw a line round her neck.

sentences.original: êkwah êkos îsi sôhki mitonih êh-pimipayiyit, êh-wayacâwipitikot.
sentences.text: êkwa êkosi isi sôhki mitoni ê-pimipayiyit ê-wayacâwipitikot
sentences.english: Then he began to ride at a swift pace, dragging her as she ran.
She was almost dead for want of breath.
They ran into sight of the place;
there were very many tents.
Then the man halted.
“Put on your clothes,” he told his wife.
“No.
Let me go bare.”
“No.
Put on your blouse.”
She sat there, naked.
Then the man began to be worried.
“Quickly put on your blouse!”
At last he made her put on her blouse.
Then they went home.
When they got there, they went into the tent.
Then the woman was very sick.
Then the man was asked, “What have you been doing to your wife?”
“Nothing at all.”

sentences.original: êkwah iskwêw, tânisi êh-tôtâsk kiwîkimâkan ôh-âhkosiyan ?
sentences.english: Then the woman, “What did your husband do to you, that you are ill?”
“I had to run far in a naked state,” she said.

sentences.original: êkwah wîhtamawâw nâpêw, ê-sakâpêkipahat kiwîkimâkan kêkâc nipahatâhtam, itâw.
sentences.english: Then the man was told, “Because you made your wife ran on a line, she is almost dead from loss of breath,” he was told.
Then he would not answer.
At last the woman got well.
Again she set out.
She arrived at another place.
She saw a man weeping on a hilltop.
“What is it you are weeping over?”
“Because my younger sister has been killed,” he told her.
“But who are you?”
“I am your sister-in-law's husband.”
So then she went home with him.

sentences.original: itah ê-kih-minahoyit, êkotah mistahi otinam wiyâs, kwaskwêpayihôsah ê-nipahâyit.
sentences.text: ita ê-kî-minahoyit êkota mistahi otinam wiyâs kwâskwêpayihôsa ê-nipahâyit
sentences.english: There where he had killed game, she took a large amount of meat, for he had killed a jumping-deer.
“No doubt your sister-in-law will be glad when she sees you.”
Then she went home with him.
They arrived at the tipi.
“Where do you come from?
So you are alive after all.
Your husband has not killed you!” the other said to her.
“No,” she answered her; “I ran away and came here.”
sentences.footnote: This is the agreeing answer to a yes-or-no question;  if the question, as here, is put negatively, {êhag} corresponds to our “No.”

sentences.english: “Surely your husband will kill you, if he finds you;
he will kill you.
He may well come here, for all I know.”
“No,” she answered the other; “He won't be able to find me.”
“For all I know he has already come,” the other told her.

sentences.original: wîpac nâpêsisah êh-pîhtokêyit âcimoyiwah êh-takohtêyit onâpêma.
sentences.text: wîpac nâpêsisa ê-pîhtokêyit âcimoyiwa ê-takohtêyit onâpêma
sentences.english: Soon a boy came into the tipi and said that her husband had come.
“Flee, Sister-in-Law,” the other told her.
“No! Please let me hide indoors.”
“Very well,” the other told her.
Then she hid her.
Presently he came into the tent.
“Where is my wife?”
“She has not come here at any time.”

sentences.original: sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw; kotakihk mîna itohtêw.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw kotakihk mîna itohtêw
sentences.english: The man went away; he went to another place.
Then she came forth.
She feared him; then she came forth; she fled.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê pasahcâhk êh-ayât, êhâh, kimiskâtin! k-êtikot, otihtimanihk êh-otinikot onâpêmah.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê pasahcâhk ê-ayât kâ-itikot otihtimanihk ê-otinikot onâpêma
sentences.english: Then, at one time, when she was in a ravine, “Haha, I have found you!” said her husband, grabbing her by the shoulder.
He struck her with a tomahawk.
He knocked her out of her senses.
She came back to consciousness.
Again he struck her.
Then for a long time she was senseless.
Then her husband left her there.
Her sister-in-law found her.
On a hide she dragged her back to the tent.
For a long time she remained unconscious.
Then that Salteau fled.
“I have killed her!” he thought.
But his wife recovered her senses.

sentences.original: êkây êkwah, miyw-âyâyinih, êkâya wîkim kîhtwâm.
sentences.english: “Now, when you get well, do not live with him any more.”
“No,” she said.
Then the man went away.
He decided to abduct another woman, who was married.
This woman had a little girl.

sentences.original: êkwah awa kâ-kwâsihtwât mâh-mâtôyiwah mânah ocânisah.
sentences.text: êkwa awa kâ-kwâsihtwât mâh-mâtoyiwa mâna ocânisa
sentences.english: Then, when the husband was robbed of his wife, his little daughter used to weep.
He did not like that.
Then, when the band moved camp, he caught sight of his wife.
“Come here,” he told her;
“Weep!” he told her.
“No,” said the woman.
She got angry; she scolded her husband severely.

sentences.original: miton êh-pakwâtitân, êyak ôhci kotak nâpêw k-ôh-otinak, itêw.
sentences.english: “Because I hate you is why I have taken another man,” she  told him.
The woman took up a stone;
she struck her husband with it;
she cut open his face.
Then the man, “So you even wound me!”
The woman fled; she went from that place.
The man took a gun and loaded it.
He ran after her.

sentences.original: mihcêt ayîsiyiniwak êh-pimipicicik êkotah êh-pimohtêyit owîkimâkanah pâskiswêw;
sentences.text: mihcêt ayîsiyiniwak ê-pimipicicik êkota ê-pimohtêyit owîkimâkana pâskiswêw
sentences.english: As his wife was walking with a great band of people that were moving camp, he shot her;
he felled her.
“You have killed me!” she said to her husband.
“But that is just what I am trying to do!”
Then he departed.
His wife lay there.
He had nearly killed her.
Other people took her up; they placed her on a vehicle.
By the time they made camp, she was nearly dead.

sentences.original: êkwah niwîkimâkan nika-wâpamik, itwêw, mînah tânis.
sentences.english: “Please have my husband see me,” she said, “and my daughter.
I am surely going to die.”
He was told of it;
“Your wife wants you.”
“No,” he said; “No; I shall not by any possibility go to see her.”
At last, just before daylight, the woman died.
Thereupon the people moved camp.
The man did not think anything of it.
Then, when they had pitched camp, he cooked a ceremonial meal;
he invited guests.
He invited many women.
“The reason I have invited you is that I want to do mourning for my wife,” he said.

sentences.original: êkwah ocayânisiwâwah wîkiwâw kawinamwân, êh-mêkit kahkiyaw.
sentences.text: êkwa ocayânisiwâwa wîkiwâw kawinamwân ê-mêkit kahkiyaw
sentences.english: Then their belongings and their tipi were thrown down, and he gave everything away.

sentences.original: nayêstaw otakohpis êyakô pimiwitâw, ocânisah mînah.
sentences.text: nayêstaw otakohpis êwako pimiwitâw ocânisa mîna
sentences.english: Only his blanket he kept with him, and his little daughter.

sentences.original: nama kêkway pîtos kêkway ayâw êyakô ê-kîh-nipahât wîwah.
sentences.text: nama kêkway pîtos kêkway ayâw êwako ê-kî-nipahât wîwa
sentences.english: Nothing else did he keep who had slain his wife.

sentences.original: mêkwâc kâ-nâh-nôtinitocik ayahciyiniwak, nânitaw ayênâniw-mitanaw askiy êyakw ânimah kâ-kîh-ispayik.
sentences.text: mêkwâc kâ-nâh-nôtinitocik ayahciyiniwak nânitaw ayênânêw-mitanaw askiy êwako anima kâ-kî-ispayik
sentences.english: At the time when the Blackfoot were fighting among themselves, about eighty years ago, was when this happened.
Truly, he brought misery upon his little daughter, making her an orphan.
